requirements: The core contributions of the paper "Batch and match: black-box variational inference with a score-based divergence" have been reproduced.

sub_tasks.requirements: The core variational inference algorithms studied in the paper have been implemented
The Batch and Match (BaM) algorithm for Variational Inference (VI) has been implemented as outlined in Section 3 and Algorithm 1.

BaM has been implemented such that, at minimum, it takes batch size, inverse regularization (learning rate), the target score function, the initial mean and the initial covariance as input and outputs the estimated variational parameters.
The 'batch' step from BaM has been correctly implemented as outlined in Section 3 and Algorithm 1.

The 'batch' step in BaM has been implemented such that at each iteration the current estimated mean and covariance matrix are used to sample $z_b$ from a Gaussian for $b = 1, \dots, B$, where B is the batch size.

The 'batch' step in BaM has been implemented such that at each iteration the "score" ($\nabla \log (p)$, where $p$ is the density of the target distribution)) can be and is computed for each sampled $z_b$.
The 'batch' step in BaM has been implemented such that the sample statistics are accumulated following equations (6) and (7), as shown in step 5 of Algorithm 1.
The 'match' step from BaM has been correctly implemented as outlined in Section 3 and Algorithm 1.

The 'match' step in BaM has been implemented such that at each iteration, the U and V matrices have been implemented using the accumulated statistics from the 'batch' step, as outlined in equations (10) and (11) and in step 6 of Algorithm 1.

The 'match' step in BaM has been implemented such that at each iteration, the U and V matrices are used along with the accumulated statistics and the inverse regularization (learning rate) to update the estimated mean and covariance using equations (12) and (13) as shown in step 7 of algorithm 1.
The BaM 'match' step has been implemented such that it optionally supports updating covariance using the update in Lemma B.3, asserting that B<D
BaM has been implemented such that it generally follows the steps in Algorithm 1.
Automatic Differentiation Variational Inference (ADVI) has been implemented as outlined in the provided Algorithm 2 code snippet, supporting a Gaussian variational approximation with full covariance.

ADVI is implemented such that, at minimum, it takes batch size, a learning rate or learning rate schedule, the unnormalized target log density, the initial mean and the initial covariance as input and outputs the estimated variational parameters.

ADVI has been implemented such that at each iteration, a mini-batch of samples is drawn from the current approximate distribution $q_{t}$, a Gaussian with some mean $\mu_{t}$ and covariance $\Sigma_{t}$.

ADVI has been implemented such that at each iteration, a stochastic estimate of the (negative) Evidence Lower Bound (ELBO) is computed using the reparameterization trick or an equivalent approach for samples \(z_b\sim q_{t}\). Specifically, the code forms \(-\sum_b [\log p(z_b) - \log q_t(z_b)]\).

ADVI has been implemented such that the gradient of the negative ELBO (with respect to the variational parameters) is used to update the variational parameters (e.g. via the Adam optimizer) as shown in step 5 of Algorithm 2
Overall, the implemented ADVI procedure follows the logic of Algorithm 2

Automatic Differentiation Variational Inference (ADVI) "Score" variant has been implemented, such that it is identical to the ADVI implementation but rather than using ELBO loss, it uses score-based divergence.

Automatic Differentiation Variational Inference (ADVI) "Fisher" variant has been implemented, such that it is identical to the ADVI implementation but rather than using ELBO loss, it uses Fisher divergence
The Gaussian Score Matching (GSM) approach for Variational Inference (VI) has been implemented as described in Algorithm 3, supporting a Gaussian variational approximation with full covariance.

GSM has been implemented such that it takes, at minimum, a batch size, the unnormalized target density, the initial mean and the initial covariance as input and outputs the estimated variational parameters.

GSM has been implemented such that at each iteration, a mini-batch of samples is drawn from the current approximate distribution $q_{t}$, a Gaussian with some mean $\mu_{t}$ and covariance $\Sigma_{t}$.
GSM has been implemented such that at each iteration, for each sampled $z_b$ the target distribution's score \$s_b = \nabla \log \tilde{p}(z_b)$ is computed
GSM has been implemented such that at each iteration, for each sampled $z_b$, the updated for mean and covariance are estimated following steps 6 and 7 of Algorithm 3.
GSM has been implemented such that each iteration, the variational mean and covariance are updated following step 9 of Algorithm 3.
Overall, the GSM procedure has been implemented so that it follows the main steps of Algorithm 3.
The results of section 5.1 have been replicated
Code has been implemented for measuring the forward and reverse empirical KL divergences between two distributions
The results of Figure 5.1 and Figure E.3 have been replicated

The forward and reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with normal tails ($t=1$) and varying skews measured over VI iterations for BaM and ADVI show that BaM converges faster (in terms of number of iterations) than ADVI.

The forward and reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with normal tails ($t=1$) and varying skews measured over VI iterations for BaM and ADVI show that, compared to ADVI, BaM converges to a higher value in terms of forward KL divergence and to a similar value in terms of reverse KL divergence

The reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with no skew ($s=0$) and varying tails measured over VI iterations for BaM, GSM, ADVI, Score and Fisher show that all methods converge to similar values

The reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with no skew ($s=0$) and varying tails measured over VI iterations for BaM, GSM and ADVI show that in some cases, BaM and ADVI converge to better values than GSM

The forward and reverse KL divergence between target and estimated sinh-arcsinh normal distributions with no skew ($s=0$) and varying tails measured over VI iterations for BaM and ADVI show that BaM typically converges in fewer iterations than ADVI

The results of Figure 5.4 b) from Section 5.3 have been replicated

The MSE between the reconstructed image and the sampled test image measured over the VI iterations for BaM at batch size 10 shows that BaM performs poorly (MSE greater than 0.2) at smaller batch sizes, i.e. at a batch size of 10.

The MSE between the reconstructed image and the sampled test image measured over the VI iterations for BaM at batch sizes 100 and 300 show that BaM performs competitively (MSE less than 0.05) at larger batch sizes, i.e. at a batch size of 100 and 300.

The MSE between the reconstructed image and the sampled test image measured over the VI iterations for BaM, GSM and ADVI at batch size 300 show that BaM converges an order of magnitude (or more) faster (in terms of taking less iterations to converge) than ADVI and GSM

The MSE between the reconstructed image and the sampled test image measured over the VI iterations for BaM, ADVI and AVI at batch sizes 10, 100 and 300 show that in general either BaM or ADVI or both achieve a MSE than AVI.
